study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of chest physiotherapy (CP) on pulmonary functions, dyspnea levels, functional capacity, and quality of life in patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Patients who received CP showed significant improvements in respiratory functions, oxygen saturation, functional capacity, and quality of life, along with reduced dyspnea levels compared to the control group. The control group only showed marginal improvements in functional capacity and quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (mean age 38.00 ± 7.04 years).
effective_dosage: CP and mobilization applied twice a day, totaling 8 sessions.
study_duration: From the first postoperative day until the 4th postoperative day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between executive function, eating patterns, and weight loss in the preoperative period of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that working memory predicted weight loss before surgery, and inhibitory control predicted adherence to dietary recommendations, suggesting executive function plays a role in short-term preoperative outcomes.
population_specificity: Eighty bariatric surgery patients assessed 4 weeks prior to surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between androgen excess, obesity, and metabolic disorders, and whether bariatric surgery could resolve features of PCOS secondary to obesity.
results_summary: The study found that considerable weight loss through bariatric surgery led to the complete resolution of PCOS features, supporting the hypothesis of "PCOS secondary to obesity." It also highlighted the role of androgen excess in visceral obesity and metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, particularly adolescent girls, mature women, and menopausal women with hyperandrogenic states.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on pregnancy outcomes in women with obesity and propose clinical practice recommendations for pregnancy management post-surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improved pregnancy outcomes by reducing gestational diabetes, pregnancy-induced hypertension, and macrosomia but increased risks of small-for-gestational-age fetus and prematurity. The study derived clinical recommendations from literature, guidelines, and expert opinion.
population_specificity: Women with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery and were of childbearing age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize current knowledge on the dietary intake of women during pregnancy following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found a lack of comprehensive data on dietary intake in pregnant women post-bariatric surgery, with only four studies meeting inclusion criteria. Insufficient protein intake was noted as a concern in two studies, with one linking it to poor fetal growth.
population_specificity: Women who became pregnant after bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 16-week supervised concurrent exercise program on weight loss and secondary outcomes like body composition, cardiometabolic risk, and quality of life in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study provides a detailed description of the exercise program but does not report specific results on weight loss or secondary outcomes in the abstract. It emphasizes the program's potential utility for exercise professionals and adherence to CERT criteria.
population_specificity: 80 bariatric surgery patients (60-80% women, aged 18-60, BMI ≥40 kg/m² or ≥35 kg/m² with comorbidities).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program details not quantified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of bariatric surgery on clinical periodontal conditions in patients with obesity through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in bleeding on probing or probing pocket depth before and after bariatric surgery, but it did observe a worsening of clinical attachment loss post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bariatric surgery as a curative intervention for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and review evidence on surgical modalities and mechanisms driving metabolic improvement.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery can achieve glycemic control and potentially lead to T2DM remission, with evidence from observational and randomized studies supporting its efficacy. However, discrepancies in success rates and definitions of remission across studies were noted.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the impact of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and sleeve gastrectomy (SG) on the incidence of iron deficiency in individuals undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency was common in people with obesity and worsened after RYGB (24.5% post-op vs. 12.9% pre-op), while it improved after SG (12.4% post-op vs. 36.6% pre-op). Iron deficiency-related anemia was more prevalent post-RYGB (16.7%) than post-SG (1.6%), with risk factors including premenopausal females and pre-existing iron deficiency.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity undergoing RYGB or SG, with a focus on premenopausal females and those with pre-operative iron deficiency.
effective_dosage: Prophylactic iron supplementation varied from 7 to 80 mg daily across studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize literature on changes in taste function and ingestive behavior following Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB) and Sleeve Gastrectomy (SG), focusing on methodological differences in assessing these changes.
results_summary: Studies using surveys found self-reported taste changes and reduced preference for energy-dense foods, while direct sensory techniques showed little to no change in taste perception or preference. The findings suggest alterations in food reward value rather than taste intensity, with RYGB and possibly SG linked to increased alcohol consumption and risk of alcohol use disorder.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent RYGB or SG for severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the minimum change in BMI-SDS required to improve adiposity (percentage body fat) in children and adolescents with obesity, excluding surgical interventions like bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that a reduction of at least 0.6 in mean BMI-SDS ensured a mean reduction in percentage body fat mass, with the 95% prediction interval wholly negative. The paper did not evaluate bariatric surgery, as such interventions were excluded.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 4-19 years with obesity, based on defined BMI thresholds.
study_duration: Interventions of <2 weeks were excluded; exact duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review emerging medical devices for obesity treatment, focusing on gastric and duodenal therapies, and their role for patients who struggle with weight control despite lifestyle modifications or are unfit for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study highlights a shift from traditional gastric size-reducing devices to those modulating neural and hormonal responses for early satiety, suggesting potential benefits for certain patients, but emphasizes the need for more long-term efficacy and safety data from randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Patients struggling with weight control despite lifestyle modifications and those who decline or are unfit for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the complications of bariatric surgery, particularly micronutrient deficiencies and their contribution to hyperhomocysteinemia, as well as factors influencing homocysteine concentration post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgeries like Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy often lead to micronutrient deficiencies (e.g., vitamins B6, B12, folic acid), contributing to hyperhomocysteinemia. Other factors, such as surgery type, post-surgical betaine and creatinine levels, and genetic mutations, also influence homocysteine concentration despite supplementation.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the association between obesity and pancreatic cancer (PC) and explore the potential of bariatric surgery as a therapeutic strategy for preventing and treating PC.
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery may reduce the risk of PC by targeting adipose tissue-mediated inflammation and metabolic dysregulation, potentially offering a new therapeutic approach.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of epidemiological and biological mechanisms).

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of an oral health educational/preventive program on patients undergoing gastroplasty (bariatric surgery) in preventing oral health problems.
results_summary: The intervention group showed fewer changes in enamel and dentin, reduced gingival bleeding, lower plaque index, and increased salivary flow compared to the control group, with no significant difference in incipient tooth wear between groups.
population_specificity: 109 patients undergoing gastroplasty (bariatric surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of bariatric surgery in mitigating obesity-related cognitive impairment by addressing endothelial dysfunction and blood-brain barrier disruption.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric surgery, along with dietary interventions and exercise, may help counteract obesity's negative effects on cognitive function by improving endothelial dysfunction and systemic inflammation. However, specific outcomes or data supporting this claim are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity-related cognitive impairment population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a BMI-stratified prophylactic dosing regimen of enoxaparin in preventing venous thromboembolism (VTE) in adolescents with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the dosing scheme of 40 mg vs. 60 mg enoxaparin, stratified by BMI, achieved prophylactic anti-FXa activity in 83% of adolescent patients, indicating effectiveness in VTE prevention.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-20 years with severe obesity (mean BMI 49.9 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 40 mg SC for BMI <50 kg/m², 60 mg SC for BMI ≥50 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate bariatric surgery as a renoprotective strategy by assessing its effects on CKD risk factors like type 2 diabetes and hypertension.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improved or remitted major CKD risk factors such as type 2 diabetes and hypertension, with observational studies reporting benefits in kidney function markers like estimated glomerular filtration rate and albuminuria. However, the literature is limited by study design and participant selection issues.
population_specificity: Primarily patients without preexisting CKD, though future research is suggested for those with CKD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG) as a less invasive treatment option for obesity.
results_summary: ESG produced clinically significant weight loss, with mean total body weight loss of 15.1% at 6 months and sustained results at 12-24 months. The pooled rate of severe adverse events was low (2.2%), including pain, nausea, bleeding, and peri-gastric leaks.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (total n=1772 across 8 studies).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 6 to 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize qualitative findings on patients' motives and expectations prior to undergoing bariatric surgery for weight loss.
results_summary: The study identified four global themes (physiological, emotional, cognitive, and interpersonal/environmental) and seven subthemes describing patients' presurgery experiences. Participants expected postsurgery weight loss to improve physical health, psychosocial well-being, and engagement in public and professional life.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe and complex obesity (580 participants across 28 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide evidence-based guidance on nutritional management and optimal care for pregnancy after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study formulated recommendations for periconception, antenatal, and postnatal care for women post-bariatric surgery, though many recommendations lacked high-quality evidence and require further research.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age with a history of bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery for sustained weight loss and metabolic improvement, particularly in poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) cases.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to sustained weight loss and metabolic improvements, attributed to postprandial gut peptide changes. Emerging evidence suggests gut hormone-based therapies may mimic these effects.
population_specificity: Patients with poorly controlled T2DM and varying body weights.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize literature on predictors and mechanisms of post-bariatric alcohol problems to guide future research on prevention and treatment targets.
results_summary: The study found an elevated risk of alcohol problems post-bariatric surgery, with predictors including male gender, younger age, smoking, and pre-surgical alcohol use disorder. Potential mechanisms involved surgical procedures, peptides, reward pathways, pharmacokinetics, and genetic influences.
population_specificity: Individuals who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare three different vitamin D deficiency treatment strategies before bariatric surgery and assess their impact on serum vitamin D levels after 7 weeks.
results_summary: The study found that oral treatment with 50,000 units of vitamin D significantly increased serum vitamin D levels compared to injection or combined methods after 7 weeks, with no significant differences in baseline characteristics among groups.
population_specificity: 100 patients referred for bariatric surgery with vitamin D deficiency (<30 ng/mL) at a university hospital in Isfahan, Iran.
effective_dosage: 50,000 units of vitamin D (oral, injection, or combined).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and management of bariatric surgery in severely obese adolescents, including eligibility criteria, surgical options, and outcomes.
results_summary: Early bariatric surgical intervention improves body mass index and significantly enhances cardiovascular and metabolic co-morbidities in severely obese adolescents, though referral rates remain stagnant. Recent studies provide insights into surgical options and outcomes for this population.
population_specificity: Severely obese adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of first-step laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic loop duodenal switch (LLCD) as bridging interventions for weight loss prior to bariatric surgery in patients with BMI ≥ 50 kg/m².
results_summary: The study found that both LSG and LLCD are safe and effective bridging interventions, facilitating significant weight loss (mean baseline BMI reduction from 61.26 kg/m²) before bariatric surgery. The results support their use in high-BMI patients.
population_specificity: Patients with BMI ≥ 50 kg/m² (mean baseline BMI 61.26 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if preoperative weight loss using an intragastric balloon (IGB) reduces post-surgical morbidity and mortality in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative IGB did not reduce post-surgical morbidity, hospital stay, or re-operation rates but achieved significantly higher weight loss compared to a diet program.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity undergoing gastric bypass or vertical gastrectomy (65.6% women, mean age ~43 years).
study_duration: IGB inserted within 6 months before surgery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of breathing exercises with linear and nonlinear load devices on reversing diaphragm dysfunction and reducing atelectasis prevalence after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Both groups maintained respiratory muscle endurance post-surgery, and the treatment helped control atelectasis without causing clinical repercussions.
population_specificity: 40 morbidly obese women (BMI > 40 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the early effects of a dissonance-based group intervention on health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and wellbeing in women who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery.
results_summary: The study found no difference in HRQoL between the intervention and control groups at 1-year post-RYGB surgery, though all scales improved in both groups from pre- to post-surgery. The dissonance-based intervention did not show early effects on HRQoL.
population_specificity: Women who underwent RYGB surgery, recruited from 5 hospitals in Sweden, with a mean age of 44.7 years and mean pre-surgery BMI of 40.8.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to create and validate a population-based risk score to predict the severity of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in patients with obesity, particularly to aid in selecting high-risk patients for further polysomnography.
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence of OSA (96.3%) among obese patients, with 74.5% having moderate/severe OSA. A prediction model incorporating sex, BMI, diabetes, and age showed excellent discrimination (C statistic = 83%), leading to the creation of a clinical OSA risk chart.
population_specificity: 161 patients with obesity from the Obesity Center of the Catholic University Hospital in Rome, Italy.
study_duration: Cross-sectional analysis at baseline of an ongoing long-term study (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the late adverse events and mortality rates over a 7-year period following gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy compared to matched control groups with obesity.
results_summary: The study found lower 7-year mortality in both gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy groups compared to controls, but higher risks of hospital admission for gastrointestinal and nutritional disorders, with gastric bypass showing higher risks than sleeve gastrectomy. No significant association was found for psychiatric disorders except for alcohol dependence in the gastric bypass group.
population_specificity: Patients in France who underwent gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy in 2009, matched with control patients with obesity based on age, sex, BMI category, and baseline antidiabetic or insulin therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize past, current, and future pharmacological efforts targeting metabolic syndrome, with emphasis on CNS-targeting drugs for obesity and its comorbidities.
results_summary: The abstract highlights weight loss as a core strategy against metabolic syndrome, achievable through bariatric surgery, lifestyle changes, or pharmacology, but does not provide specific results on bariatric surgery's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on metabolic syndrome and obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if baseline circulating succinate levels could predict type 2 diabetes remission after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Baseline succinate concentrations were found to be an independent predictor of diabetes remission post-surgery, with lower levels associated with higher remission rates. The study also noted that succinate levels decreased after bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: 45 obese patients with diabetes (initial cohort) and 88 obese patients with diabetes (validation cohort).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile existing evidence on the physiological mechanisms behind weight loss and metabolic improvements following sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
results_summary: The study found that SG leads to significant weight loss and metabolic improvements through mechanisms such as restricted food intake, altered nutrient absorption, hormonal changes, gut motility adjustments, microbial community shifts, and inflammatory responses. These changes collectively contribute to the procedure's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare postoperative opioid requirements and pain management outcomes between liposomal bupivacaine and standard bupivacaine injections at laparoscopic port sites during bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in postoperative hospital opioid use, pain scores, or complications between the two groups, though more patients in the standard bupivacaine group did not require narcotics at home on postoperative days 2-4.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) or vertical sleeve gastrectomy (VSG), mean age 39.2 years, 79% women, mean BMI 45.0.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess adherence to supplementation, micronutrient intake, and biochemistry in adolescents through 5 years after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
results_summary: Over 75% of adolescents completed dietary assessments over 5 years, with adherence to supplementation ranging between 44-61%. Iron deficiency and vitamin D insufficiency were prevalent, particularly among non-adherent females, while adherence to supplements was associated with more favorable biochemistry.
population_specificity: Adolescents (mean age 16.5 years, 67% female) with a mean BMI of 45.5 kg/m² undergoing RYGB.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a 2-year group-based lifestyle intervention starting approximately 2 years after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) compared with usual care in preventing weight regain and improving metabolic risk factors.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in weight regain between the lifestyle intervention group and the usual care group. Participants who reported higher physical activity levels had smaller weight regain, but the intervention itself did not significantly impact weight regain or metabolic risk factors.
population_specificity: 165 patients who had undergone RYGB surgery, with a mean of 21 months post-surgery (range 14-32 months).
effective_dosage: 16 group meetings over 2 years (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining bariatric surgery with physical exercise enhances weight loss and improves obesity-related comorbidities.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that exercise after bariatric surgery did not significantly enhance weight loss (SMD = 0.15; 95% CI = -0.02, 0.32; p = 0.094). However, variability in exercise protocols made definitive conclusions premature.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the complex mechanisms of bariatric surgery at the gut-brain level using the pig model.
results_summary: The study explored bariatric surgery in the pig model to elucidate its effects on gut-brain interactions, but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. The broader context suggests it contributes to understanding metabolic and cognitive improvements.
population_specificity: Pig model (with parallels drawn to obese human patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and impact of bariatric surgery after breast cancer treatment, focusing on safety, weight loss, and breast cancer recurrence.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was well tolerated with minimal adverse events (one abdominal wall hematoma) and resulted in significant weight loss (28.1% at 1 year, 28.2% at 2 years). Only one breast cancer recurrence occurred over a median follow-up of 11.7 years post-diagnosis and 5.3 years post-surgery.
population_specificity: 13 female breast cancer survivors (69.2% stage I, 23.1% stage II) with a median age of 52 at surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the scientific literature on vitamin K status among bariatric surgery patients, including pre- and post-surgery candidates and pregnant women with a history of BS.
results_summary: The review found that patients undergoing major malabsorptive bariatric surgeries are at higher risk of vitamin K deficiency, but evidence on supplementation efficacy, dosage, and screening protocols remains unclear. Current treatment protocols are experiential, and further studies are needed to address these gaps.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery candidates (n = 750), post-BS patients (n = 1442), and pregnant women with a history of BS (n = 83).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between disordered eating behaviors (DEBs) and weight outcomes following bariatric surgery, as well as explore interventions for DEBs.
results_summary: The study found that while DEBs often remit after surgery without intervention, persistent or new DEBs postoperatively can negatively impact weight outcomes. Preoperative DEBs had little effect on weight, but postoperative DEBs showed stronger associations with concurrent weight measures.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients with or at risk for disordered eating behaviors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of bariatric surgery on central 24-hour blood pressure changes in severely obese adults, including circadian patterns and hypertension resolution.
results_summary: The study found a substantial reduction in central 24-hour systolic blood pressure 12 months after bariatric surgery, even in patients with normal baseline blood pressure. Secondary endpoints also showed improvements in diastolic and peripheral blood pressure parameters.
population_specificity: Severely obese adults (77% women, mean BMI 42.6 kg/m², 39% with hypertension).
study_duration: 12 months, with intermediate evaluations at 1, 3, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the diagnostic challenges and rare complications (duodenal perforation) in patients with altered anatomy post-RYGB bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that duodenal perforations in RYGB patients are rare but diagnostically challenging due to the absence of pneumoperitoneum and difficult access to the excluded segment. Laparoscopic exploration was recommended despite negative diagnostic findings.
population_specificity: A 38-year-old woman with a history of RYGB presenting with acute abdominal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop post-operative management guidelines for bariatric surgery based on expert consensus from Spanish obesity societies.
results_summary: The study reviewed 17 post-operative management topics and produced 47 recommendations, derived from systematic reviews and meta-analyses, with broad expert agreement (mean 54 voters per statement). The guidelines emphasize clinician expertise and long-term follow-up for optimal patient care.
population_specificity: Post-bariatric surgery patients (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether remission of type 2 diabetes induced by bariatric surgery influences kidney disease markers and if baseline gut hormone levels modify these associations.
results_summary: Remission of diabetes at 5 years post-surgery was associated with lower risk for moderate/severe albuminuria and stabilized CKD risk but not with eGFR. Lower preoperative kidney function and higher CKD risk reduced the likelihood of diabetes remission.
population_specificity: 737 bariatric surgery patients with type 2 diabetes from a multicenter cohort study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of weight loss strategies, including bariatric surgery, on blood pressure in obese patients with hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, along with other weight loss strategies, had a positive effect on blood pressure reduction, though the magnitude and durability of this effect varied. Long-term effects remain uncertain due to insufficient follow-up data.
population_specificity: Obese patients with hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and glycemic effects of duodenal mucosal resurfacing (DMR) in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) irrespective of body mass index changes.
results_summary: DMR improved glycemic control (reduced HbA1c, FPG, and HOMA-IR) and modestly reduced weight, with effects sustained at 12 months. The procedure was found feasible and safe, with most adverse events being mild.
population_specificity: Patients with T2D (HbA1c 7.5%-10.0%) and BMI 24-40 on stable oral glucose-lowering medication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether exercise training could mitigate bone loss induced by bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass).
results_summary: Exercise training significantly reduced bone mineral density loss at multiple skeletal sites and attenuated bone turnover markers compared to surgery alone, though it did not affect biochemical markers like vitamin D or calcium levels.
population_specificity: Seventy women aged 25-55 with severe obesity who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
effective_dosage: Supervised, 6-month exercise program (specific regimen not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential psychosocial risk factors, including sex hormone management, that may impact surgical clearance and treatment recommendations for transgender bariatric surgery candidates.
results_summary: The study did not present specific results on bariatric surgery outcomes but highlighted the lack of research on transgender bariatric surgery candidates and the need to address psychosocial risk factors.
population_specificity: Transgender individuals in the USA who are obese and may pursue bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between psychiatric comorbidity and weight regain in postbariatric surgery patients through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that higher rates of postbariatric surgery eating psychopathology were associated with weight regain, with a meta-analysis showing significantly higher odds of eating psychopathology in the weight regain group (OR = 2.2). However, the association between general psychopathology and weight regain was inconsistent across studies.
population_specificity: Postbariatric surgery patients, predominantly women (87.6%), who underwent bypass (66.8%), gastric banding (32.1%), or sleeve (1.1%) procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review studies on postprandial hypertriglyceridaemia, its genetic and lifestyle determinants, associated conditions, and therapeutic aspects.
results_summary: The abstract summarizes a narrative review of studies on postprandial hypertriglyceridaemia, highlighting influencing factors (genetic, lifestyle, and underlying conditions) but does not specifically address bariatric surgery outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare outcomes of bariatric surgery between patients with NAFLD and those without, focusing on safety and efficacy.
results_summary: NAFLD patients had 35% lower inpatient mortality, shorter hospital stays, and reduced risks of improper wound healing and post-operative infection compared to non-NAFLD patients, though with slightly higher hospital charges. No differences were found in bleeding or surgical revision rates.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing bariatric surgery, stratified by presence of NAFLD (15,607 with NAFLD, 286,699 without).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether weight loss, including through bariatric surgery, improves central hemodynamics in obese patients without clinically overt heart failure.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery, along with dietary interventions, led to significant weight loss (median 43 kg) and improvements in central hemodynamics, including reduced heart rate, mean arterial pressure, and pulmonary artery pressures. These changes were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Obese patients without clinically overt heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the prevalence and mechanisms of macro- and micronutrient deficiencies in obese and post-bariatric surgery individuals and summarize data on screening and supplementation strategies.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgeries are effective for weight loss in morbidly obese patients but commonly lead to micronutrient deficiencies and malnutrition, necessitating pre- and postoperative nutritional assessment and corrections.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (BMI ≥ 35).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review obesity definitions, epidemiology, pathophysiology, comorbidities, and management options, including bariatric surgery, in the paediatric population.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on bariatric surgery's effects but indicates it discusses recommendations and relevant aspects of the procedure for paediatric patients.
population_specificity: Paediatric population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate trends in anthropometric and clinical outcomes, including body composition changes, over 3 years following sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
results_summary: Fat mass significantly decreased 1 year post-surgery but partially rebounded by 3 years, while fat-free mass stabilized after initial decline. Weight loss failure increased over time, and metabolic markers (e.g., HDL-C, HbA1c) showed sustained improvements despite FM regain.
population_specificity: 60 patients (55% women, mean age 44.7 ± 8.7 years) who underwent SG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of bariatric surgery on weight loss and resolution of obesity-related comorbidities in the Indigenous Ontario population compared to non-Indigenous patients.
results_summary: The study found that weight loss and resolution of obesity-related comorbidities (diabetes, hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease) were similar between Indigenous and non-Indigenous patients. However, Indigenous patients had higher baseline rates of hypertension and diabetes.
population_specificity: Indigenous and non-Indigenous adults in Ontario, Canada, who underwent bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Data collected from March 2010 to 2018, with 1-year follow-up for BMI change.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of microbiota modulation, including bariatric surgery, on obesity and associated metabolic dysfunctions.
results_summary: The review highlights bariatric surgery as a model for understanding metabolic and inflammatory effects, noting its association with changes in gut microbiota composition. It suggests potential benefits but calls for more research to clarify these relationships.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of animal and human studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish management rules for thyroid disorders in obese individuals, focusing on distinguishing obesity-related changes from pathological thyroid conditions.
results_summary: The study found that obesity-related thyroid abnormalities, such as elevated TSH and hypoechoic thyroid gland, often normalize with weight loss, suggesting that thyroid hormone replacement may not be necessary for asymptomatic obese patients.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, specifically a case of diet-induced obesity with thyroid abnormalities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the associations between obesity, metabolic syndrome (MetS), NAFLD, and diabetic microvascular complications, and to evaluate the potential effects of lifestyle interventions and bariatric surgery on these complications.
results_summary: The study found that obesity and MetS are linked to diabetic kidney disease, retinopathy, and peripheral neuropathy, though results were inconsistent. Bariatric surgery may help prevent or slow these complications, but more evidence is needed.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), obesity, metabolic syndrome, and/or NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the 30-day unplanned readmission rate after bariatric surgery and identify risk factors and common causes for readmission.
results_summary: The study found a 4.7% unplanned readmission rate, with significant differences between bariatric procedures (gastric banding 3.1%, sleeve gastrectomy 4.5%, gastric bypass 5.7%). The main causes of readmission were abdominal pain, peritonitis, nausea/vomiting, and bleeding.
population_specificity: Adult patients who underwent bariatric surgery in France between 2013 and 2016.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate dietary modifications during the preoperative and postoperative periods of bariatric surgery and assess the impact of preoperative nutritional intervention.
results_summary: Energy intake significantly decreased from program inclusion to one year post-surgery. Preoperative intervention led to increased intake of nuts, vegetables, poultry, rabbit, fruit, fish, and skimmed milk products, while decreasing bread, soft drinks, and pastry. These changes were mostly maintained one year after surgery.
population_specificity: 60 consecutive morbidly obese patients who underwent bariatric surgery between 2010 and 2014 at Hospital del Mar.
study_duration: Preoperative intervention and follow-up until one year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review international evidence-based guidelines to develop a structured clinical pathway for managing overweight and obesity, including the role of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study identified that bariatric surgery can be offered to individuals with a BMI ≥35 kg/m², as part of a comprehensive approach to weight management. It emphasized long-term measures for weight maintenance post-surgery.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight or obesity (BMI ≥35 kg/m² for bariatric surgery consideration).
study_duration: Not specified for surgery; lifestyle interventions recommended for at least 6-12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on asthma outcomes in obese asthmatic patients.
results_summary: The review found improvements in asthma control, exacerbation risk, hospitalizations, medication use, and airway hyperresponsiveness, with some patients no longer requiring asthma treatment. However, the studies had limitations such as small sample sizes, lack of control arms, and non-standardized outcome measures.
population_specificity: Obese asthmatic patients
study_duration: Variable, mostly 1 year, with some studies reporting up to 5 years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current literature on medical tourism, focusing on applications, ethics, and economics, with specific attention to bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Patients seeking bariatric surgery abroad are motivated by lower costs and reduced wait times, but complication rates are high (up to 56%), including infections and poor outcomes. The lack of standardization in quality and safety raises concerns.
population_specificity: Patients seeking elective bariatric surgery through medical tourism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the incidence of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) using physiologic measures.
results_summary: The study found a high incidence of GERD (66.6%) after LSG, with a significant increase in DeMeester scores, while LRYGB showed no significant increase in GERD. Nonacid reflux increased significantly after both procedures.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity without preexisting GERD in a tertiary care teaching hospital in India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to retrospectively analyze the safety and effectiveness of converting from LAGB and LSG to OAGB in patients who experienced weight regain or late complications.
results_summary: The study found that OAGB is a safe and effective revisional procedure after failed restrictive bariatric surgery, with significant improvements in BMI and remission of co-morbidities such as hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia. Major complications were recorded but not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent conversion from LAGB (196) and LSG (104) to OAGB across 10 high-volume Italian bariatric surgery centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel, fully covered stent specifically designed to treat acute and early leaks following laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The stent demonstrated 100% technical success and 78.37% clinical success in treating leaks, but had a 21.62% migration rate and higher severe adverse event rates, particularly in the postpyloric position.
population_specificity: Patients with acute and early post-laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy leaks (n=37).
study_duration: Mean stent dwell time was 29.08 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in gut microbiota after surgical (adjustable gastric banding or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) versus medical weight loss in adults with diabetes and obesity.
results_summary: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) showed the most significant changes in gut microbiota, including an increase in potentially beneficial bacteria like Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, while adjustable gastric banding (AGB) reduced microbial diversity. Weight loss and glycemic improvements were similar across all groups.
population_specificity: Female adults with diabetes and obesity (75% Black, mean age 51 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify changes in body composition (lean body mass, body fat mass, and bone mass) during the first year after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in BMI, body fat mass, and lean body mass, along with improvements in lipid profiles and serum albumin levels, indicating the effectiveness of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in altering body composition.
population_specificity: Fifty patients who underwent bariatric surgery and maintained follow-ups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on glucose metabolism and its superiority over intensive lifestyle/medical management in improving diabetes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgeries like RYGB, VSG, and BPD significantly improve diabetes in most patients, often before substantial weight loss, with efficacy superior to non-surgical interventions. The mechanisms behind these metabolic changes remain partially understood but involve insulin sensitivity, hepatic glucose production, and islet function.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity and diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current data on the metabolic effects of fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT), including its potential role in obesity and glucose metabolism, and compare it with interventions like bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery interventions were noted to partially or completely restore gut microbiota dysbiosis, leading to weight reduction and metabolic improvements. However, the abstract primarily focuses on FMT's effects, with limited direct data on bariatric surgery's metabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: Obese subjects and those with metabolic syndrome or type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze and critically appraise the literature regarding optimal therapeutic strategies for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The abstract highlights lifestyle interventions (dietary changes, physical exercise, weight loss) and metformin as cornerstone treatments for T2DM in postmenopausal women, but does not mention bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the predictive role of C-reactive protein (CRP) in the early diagnosis of postoperative complications (leak and intra-abdominal infections) after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB).
results_summary: The study found that a CRP value lower than 6.1 mg/dl on postoperative day 1 (POD1) could help rule out early postoperative complications, with high diagnostic accuracy (AUC 0.92). The pooled prevalence of complications was 9.8%, and CRP demonstrated strong positive and negative likelihood ratios (13.6 and 0.16, respectively).
population_specificity: Patients undergoing LSG (57.7%) or LRYGB (42.3%), totaling 1401 patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG) as a minimally invasive weight loss intervention compared to conventional surgical sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The study found that ESG resulted in significant weight loss (%TBWL and %EWL) at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months, with a low rate of severe adverse events (1%) and a higher rate of mild adverse events (72%). The results suggest ESG is a promising alternative to conventional bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: 1542 patients from nine studies, likely individuals with obesity seeking weight loss intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how changes in energy balance and body composition influenced the rate of weight loss over one year following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: The study found significant BMI reduction (from 45 ± 2 kg/m² to 29 ± 3 kg/m²) at 12 months post-surgery, with the highest rate of weight loss at 6 months due to energy imbalance caused by restricted energy intake despite metabolic adaptation.
population_specificity: 18 women with BMI ≥ 40 and ≤ 50 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG) using a uniform "U" stitch pattern across different BMI categories, while assessing metabolic and body composition changes.
results_summary: ESG demonstrated significant weight loss (>10% TWL and >25% EWL at 6 months) across all BMI categories, with reductions in adipose tissue and low serious adverse event rates (1.03%). Male sex, younger age, and higher BMI predicted better outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight and obesity (classes I, II, and III) from 7 multicenter cohorts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the peri- and postoperative outcomes of intravenous anesthesia with propofol versus desflurane anesthesia in obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the two anesthetic regimens in terms of postoperative nausea and pain, awakening time, peritoneal stretch, or the use of perioperative muscle relaxants. Both groups showed similar outcomes, with no clinically meaningful variations.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass at a nonacademic primary referral center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of prophylactic inferior vena cava filters (IVCFs) on in-hospital mortality, thromboembolic events, and healthcare costs in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: Prophylactic IVCFs were associated with higher rates of in-hospital mortality or pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, longer hospital stays, and increased costs compared to no IVCF use. The study concluded that prophylactic IVCFs worsened clinical outcomes and resource utilization.
population_specificity: Obese patients who underwent bariatric surgery in the U.S. from 2005 to 2015.

study_goal: The researchers excluded bariatric surgery patients to analyze weight course in type 2 diabetes patients without surgical intervention.
results_summary: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery (n=19) had a distinct BMI course and were excluded from the study, so no direct results on bariatric surgery's effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (n=450, age 63±9 years, 58% men, diabetes duration 7-18 years), excluding those who underwent bariatric surgery (n=19).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and risks of Roux en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery versus standard non-surgical treatment for obese patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that RYGB significantly improves T2D outcomes compared to medical therapy, but postoperative benefits and complications vary by patient subgroups. Long-term complications and vascular events remain key knowledge gaps.
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the decision-making process of a single-day bariatric MDT clinic and assess whether MDT decisions were implemented.
results_summary: The study found MDT agreement for 55% of patients, with 45% disagreement among team members. The MDT plan was followed in 78% of cases, and 85% of patients ultimately underwent bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: 200 consecutive bariatric surgery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop evidence-based Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) guidelines for bariatric surgery to optimize perioperative care.
results_summary: The study established consensus guidelines for 14 essential ERAS elements in bariatric surgery, including preoperative weight loss programs, dietary adjustments, reduced opioid use, and early postoperative follow-up, to improve surgical efficiency and recovery.
population_specificity: Canadian bariatric surgeons and patients from six provinces and ten bariatric centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how obesity affects the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and clinical application of anesthetic agents, with a focus on enhanced recovery for obese patients.
results_summary: The study summarized the interactions between obesity and anesthetic drugs, emphasizing their PK, PD, and clinical use to improve recovery in obese patients.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery or requiring anesthesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine sleep quality and its clinical correlates in post-operative sleeve gastrectomy patients with loss-of-control (LOC) eating.
results_summary: Poor sleep quality was common (58.6%) and significantly associated with greater eating-disorder psychopathology, poorer physical and mental functioning, night eating, perceived stress, and less % excess weight loss. Sleep quality also predicted mental functioning in regression analyses.
population_specificity: Post-operative sleeve gastrectomy patients with LOC eating (N=145).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the potential of different biochemical markers for evaluating liver steatosis in morbidly obese patients before and after sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery improved liver steatosis in morbidly obese patients, with the liver fat score being the most accurate biochemical marker correlating with MR spectroscopy results. Mean BMI decreased to 28.3 ± 3.7 kg/m² 12 months post-surgery.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing sleeve gastrectomy at Garcilaso Clinic, Madrid, Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance and outcomes of a publicly funded obesity management service, including the use and effectiveness of bariatric surgery among other interventions.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was one of the intensive interventions trialed, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for it. Clinically significant weight loss was achieved in 36% of patients who continued beyond initial medical review, with 47% achieving weight stabilization.
population_specificity: New patients with obesity attending the Canberra Obesity Management Service from July 2016 to June 2017.
study_duration: Follow-up data was collated until June 2018 (approximately 1-2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of trocar site infiltration versus bilateral subcostal transversus abdominis plane block (TAP) in controlling postoperative pain in patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: The study found that TAP block resulted in statistically significantly less pain at the 6th hour post-surgery during resting and coughing compared to trocar site infiltration, but other pain measurements showed no significant differences. The researchers concluded that both methods yield similar pain control, but trocar site infiltration is preferable due to faster application and fewer side effects.
population_specificity: 45 patients (29 female, 13 male) with a median age of 41 and median BMI of 48 who underwent LSG.
study_duration: Postoperative pain assessment (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of liraglutide 1.8 mg in patients with persistent or recurrent type 2 diabetes after metabolic surgery.
results_summary: The study found that liraglutide improved glycemic control and reduced bodyweight in patients with persistent or recurrent type 2 diabetes post-metabolic surgery, supporting its use as adjunctive treatment.
population_specificity: Adults who had undergone Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or vertical sleeve gastrectomy and had persistent or recurrent type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy on remission of type 2 diabetes and β-cell function in obese patients.
results_summary: The study is designed to measure the proportion of participants achieving complete remission of type 2 diabetes (HbA1c ≤6.0% without medication) and β-cell function (via disposition index) one year after surgery, but results are not yet available (pre-results).
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe current concepts on childhood and adolescent obesity, focusing on its sequela and the role of metabolic and bariatric surgery in treatment.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is increasingly considered for carefully selected adolescents with obesity, alongside lifestyle modification, and may help address comorbidities that persist into adulthood.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms by which metabolic surgery protects islet function in diabetic patients with obesity.
results_summary: The study found that metabolic surgery improves β-cell function by reducing glucotoxicity and chronic inflammation, enhancing gut hormone activity (GLP-1 and PYY), and activating bile acid signaling pathways. These mechanisms collectively contribute to better islet function preservation.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent findings on bile acids and their receptors in mediating the metabolic benefits of bariatric surgery and explore their potential as therapeutic targets for obesity and metabolic diseases.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is highly effective for significant, sustainable weight loss and improves metabolic conditions like type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular diseases. Bile acids are emerging as key signaling molecules mediating these benefits, though underlying molecular mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of bariatric surgery effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize current knowledge on the prevalence of binge eating disorder (BED) in presurgical bariatric patients and critically evaluate assessment tools for BED.
results_summary: The study found that BED prevalence in bariatric populations varied widely (2%-53%) due to inconsistent assessment methods and methodological weaknesses. Clinical interviews, the preferred diagnostic tool, were used in only 12 of the 21 reviewed studies.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery candidates with potential binge eating disorder (BED).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of acarbose, sitagliptin, verapamil, liraglutide, and pasireotide on post-bariatric hypoglycaemia (PBH) after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: Acarbose and pasireotide significantly improved nadir glucose levels and reduced hypoglycaemia during mixed-meal tolerance tests, with acarbose also reducing hyperglycaemia. Sitagliptin lowered nadir glucose, while verapamil and liraglutide had no effect on hypoglycaemia.
population_specificity: 11 women who had undergone Roux-en-Y gastric bypass with documented hypoglycaemia.
effective_dosage: Acarbose 50 mg daily for 1 week, sitagliptin 100 mg daily for 1 week, verapamil 120 mg daily for 1 week, liraglutide 1.2 mg daily for 3 weeks, pasireotide 300 μg as a single dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immunomodulatory effects of sevoflurane versus propofol anesthesia in obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes a planned pilot trial with no outcome data reported.
population_specificity: 48 obese patients with a BMI ≥ 35 kg/m² undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of weight loss after bariatric surgery on thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels in euthyroid patients with morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery significantly reduced TSH and free thyroxine (T4) levels in obese patients, with the decline in TSH associated with excess BMI loss over 12 months.
population_specificity: Euthyroid patients with morbid obesity (129 patients, 92 women) and a control group (31 individuals, 21 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) bariatric surgery on the resting energy expenditure (REE) to fat-free mass (FFM) ratio at 6 and 12 months postoperatively.
results_summary: At 6 months, 5 of 13 studies showed a reduction in the REE/FFM ratio without significant summary effects. At 12 months, there was a significant mean reduction of 1.95 kcal/kg in FFM.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) bariatric surgery (n=406 at 6 months, n=713 at 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of bariatric surgery on gut hormone physiology, bone remodeling, and the reproductive axis, including its impact on weight loss, insulin sensitivity, and endocrine systems.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery demonstrated efficacy in sustained weight loss and improvement in comorbidities, with rapid, weight-loss-independent improvements in insulin release and sensitivity. It also showed positive effects on bone density via gut hormones but potential counterbalancing effects from weight loss, and marked improvements in reproductive health for both men and women.
population_specificity: Human obesity patients, including women with infertility/PCOS and men with hypogonadism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of offset heart rate biofeedback in reducing cue-elicited alcohol craving among risky drinkers.
results_summary: Offset heart rate biofeedback significantly reduced heart rate variability and self-reported craving in response to alcohol cues, but did not affect anxiety levels.
population_specificity: 26 participants who engaged in harmful or hazardous drinking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Buzhong Yiqi decoction combined with biofeedback electrical stimulation on pelvic floor muscle strength and quality of life in postpartum stress urinary incontinence (PSUI) patients.
results_summary: The study group showed improved urinary incontinence, higher pelvic floor muscle strength (class I and II fibers), better muscle tension, improved urodynamics, higher treatment efficiency, and enhanced quality of life compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Postpartum stress urinary incontinence (PSUI) patients (n = 256).

study_goal: To explore the effect of mindfulness meditation combined with the BrainLink intelligent biofeedback instrument on anxiety, pain, brain fatigue, and quality of life in pancreatic cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness meditation combined with biofeedback significantly reduced anxiety and pain, improved brain fatigue relief, concentration, relaxation levels, and quality of life in pancreatic cancer patients under chemotherapy. EEG data also showed an upward trend in α and θ waves in the experimental group.
population_specificity: 145 pancreatic cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of non-invasive vagal nerve stimulation (nVNS) and heart rate variability biofeedback (HRVB) on chronic pain conditions in adults.
results_summary: HRVB showed statistically significant reductions in pain intensity, depression scores, and increased HRV coherence, while nVNS demonstrated benefits in reducing headache frequency and pain intensity. Both interventions appeared clinically beneficial, but insufficient literature exists to strongly support either approach.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain conditions, including headache disorders, migraines, fibromyalgia, and chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of Mightier, a video game-based biofeedback therapy, for reducing rage attacks in youth with Tourette syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that Mightier was feasible with high retention and engagement rates, and participants showed improved rage severity across all assessment measures, with all reporting at least some improvement post-intervention.
population_specificity: Youth aged 6-12 years with a diagnosis of Tourette syndrome and rage attacks.
effective_dosage: Mean weekly play time was 38 minutes/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether combining biofeedback electric stimulation with LIPUS therapy enhances treatment outcomes for erectile dysfunction compared to LIPUS alone.
results_summary: The study found that both LIPUS alone and combined therapy significantly improved erectile function scores (IIEF-5, EHS, ESS), but no statistically significant differences were observed between the two groups. Biofeedback did not provide additional benefits over LIPUS alone.
population_specificity: 68 patients with erectile dysfunction treated at West China Fourth Hospital.
effective_dosage: Eight treatment sessions (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of eight treatment sessions (exact timeline not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of biofeedback therapy (BFT) in managing functional fecal incontinence (FFI) in children, particularly its efficacy and safety in refractory cases.
results_summary: BFT showed positive outcomes in pediatric FFI, especially for functional nonretentive fecal incontinence (FNRFI) refractory to conventional treatment, with no safety issues reported. While results were mixed for functional constipation (FC), BFT was generally considered a useful non-invasive option when used in a tailored, multimodal approach.
population_specificity: Children with functional fecal incontinence (FFI), including functional constipation (FC) and functional nonretentive fecal incontinence (FNRFI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a movement training program (MOVE) improved movement quality and recovery after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) compared to a standardized rehabilitation program without movement training (CONTROL).
results_summary: The MOVE intervention did not improve surgical peak knee extension moments (pKEM) during walking compared to CONTROL but showed less contralateral pKEM. CONTROL exhibited faster recovery on some functional tests (TUG, 30STS) at 10 weeks, though differences diminished by six months.
population_specificity: Individuals who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
study_duration: 10 weeks (intervention), with follow-up at six months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a Chinese expert consensus on the clinical practice of pelvic floor biofeedback for anorectal dysfunction, addressing controversies in indications, contraindications, and protocol formulation.
results_summary: The consensus emphasizes the need for thorough evaluation of patient condition and pelvic floor function before therapy, and highlights the importance of doctor and therapist guidance for standardized use. It recommends pelvic floor biofeedback as a major non-surgical treatment for anorectal dysfunction.
population_specificity: Patients with anorectal dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether EEG biofeedback could improve cognitive performance in children with idiopathic epilepsy syndromes and comorbid ADHD.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significant improvement in verbal working memory (forward and backward digit span tasks) but not in other cognitive assessments. EEG biofeedback was found to enhance core cognitive function in this population.
population_specificity: Children with idiopathic epilepsy syndromes and comorbid ADHD (n=36).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether visual biofeedback combined with routine occupational therapy could improve fine motor function and activities of daily living (ADL) in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study group receiving visual biofeedback showed significant improvement in fine motor function compared to the control group, but ADL improvements were similar in both groups with no significant difference.
population_specificity: Ten stroke patients aged 60-74 years with upper limb dysfunction.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were evaluated before, after, and 1.5 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of biofeedback combined with dilator therapy on sexual function in women with primary vaginismus compared to dilator therapy alone.
results_summary: Biofeedback combined with dilator therapy significantly improved overall sexual function and specific aspects (desire, arousal, orgasm, satisfaction, and pain) compared to dilator therapy alone, though no significant difference was observed for lubrication.
population_specificity: 32 women aged 18-45 with primary vaginismus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acceptability of ultrasound visual biofeedback (UVBF) and articulation intervention for families of children with cleft palate ± lip (CP±L) and assess feasibility for a full randomized control trial.
results_summary: Over 75% of families found both UVBF and articulation intervention acceptable, with high levels of enjoyment reported, though some found articulation therapy repetitive. Travel burden to clinics was a notable challenge.
population_specificity: Children with cleft palate ± lip (CP±L) and their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of biofeedback surface electromyography (sEMG) therapy versus no intervention for chronic low back pain (CLBP) in the Pakistani population.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to assess biofeedback sEMG's impact on pain intensity, disability, anxiety, depression, quality of life, and physiological parameters, but results are not yet available as it is a study protocol.
population_specificity: Pakistani adults with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether electromyographic biofeedback (EMG-BF) as an adjunct to isometric exercise improves quadriceps strength, functional impairment, and pain in MS patients.
results_summary: The biofeedback group showed significantly greater improvements in pain intensity, maximal isometric quadriceps strength, and functional disability compared to the control group after six weeks (p < 0.05). EMG-BF enhanced quadriceps muscle strength more than exercise alone, though the findings should be interpreted cautiously due to study limitations.
population_specificity: 20 MS patients with quadriceps muscle problems (10 in biofeedback group, 10 in control group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (biofeedback-guided isometric exercise program, 5 days/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding biofeedback to Virtual Reality Exposure Therapy (VRET) enhances its effectiveness in reducing physiological and perceived arousal in individuals with social anxiety.
results_summary: The study found that VRET-plus-biofeedback led to steadier reductions in frontal alpha asymmetry (FAA) during the first session and greater reductions in self-reported arousal across sessions compared to VRET alone. Both groups showed improved public speaking anxiety and overall social anxiety, with benefits sustained one month post-therapy.
population_specificity: Seventy-two individuals with high self-reported social anxiety.
effective_dosage: Three hour-long VRET sessions delivered over three consecutive weeks, with 20-minute public speaking tasks per session.

study_goal: To investigate whether core stabilization training based on biofeedback is more effective than routine core stabilization training for improving postpartum rectus abdominis muscle separation, waist circumference, and abdominal circumference.
results_summary: The experimental group using biofeedback showed significant improvements in rectus abdominis muscle distance, waist circumference, and abdominal circumference compared to the control group. Both groups improved post-treatment, but the biofeedback group outperformed the control group.
population_specificity: Thirty postpartum women aged 20-35 years with rectus diastasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback and biofeedback training could improve chess performance, physiological control, and anxiety levels in high-level chess players.
results_summary: The study found that biofeedback and neurofeedback improved heart rate variability, sensorimotor rhythm modulation, chess performance, and anxiety levels in the participant during specific and non-specific chess tasks.
population_specificity: A Chess Woman Grandmaster and Chess International Master with an ELO ranking >2350.
effective_dosage: 14 sessions of biofeedback and neurofeedback training (breathing, sensorimotor rhythm stimulation, skin conductance, temperature, and heart rate variability combined with chess work).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to cover the duration of 14 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a biofeedback-based integrated program (BBIP) on psychological health outcomes in older adults with orthostatic hypotension (OH).
results_summary: The BBIP significantly improved health-related quality of life, depression, anxiety, and fall efficacy in the intervention group, while the control group showed no significant changes. The intervention group also reported fewer problems across all EQ-5D dimensions.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with orthostatic hypotension (OH).
effective_dosage: Weekly biofeedback sessions and group education on lifestyle modification.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of stabilization with pressure feedback biofeedback training versus conventional lumbar dynamic strength exercises on pain, functionality, fear avoidance beliefs, and quality of life in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Both exercise groups showed significant improvements in pain, functionality, fear avoidance beliefs, and quality of life, but neither intervention was superior to the other. No inter-group differences were found in any measurements.
population_specificity: 34 patients aged 18-55 diagnosed with chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: 20 sessions over 4 weeks, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the therapeutic effect of biofeedback combined with psychotherapy for patients with functional constipation, anxiety, and depression disorder.
results_summary: The treatment group (biofeedback + psychotherapy) showed more significant improvements in constipation, anxiety/depression symptoms, and sleep quality compared to the control group (medication only). The effects were durable and statistically significant, particularly in reducing PSQI scores by the sixth month.
population_specificity: 120 patients with functional constipation combined with anxiety and depression disorder.
effective_dosage: Biofeedback exercise twice a day for 7 days, supplemented with psychotherapy every half-month for 2 months.
study_duration: 6 months (with primary outcomes measured at 2 and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether changes in resting heart rate variability (HRV) mediated changes in negative emotions during a 7-week clinical trial of HRV biofeedback, comparing two different biofeedback practices.
results_summary: The study found that resting HRV at pre-intervention was higher in those with lower negative emotion scores, and greater increases in resting HRV were associated with greater decreases in negative emotion. The mediation effect of HRV changes on reducing negative emotion was significant only in the condition where participants practiced slow-paced breathing to increase heart rate oscillations (Osc+).
population_specificity: Younger and older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a telemedicine-delivered HRV-BF intervention was non-inferior to an in-person intervention in reducing anxiety, depression, and stress among frontline HCWs during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: Both telemedicine and in-person HRV-BF interventions significantly reduced depression, anxiety, and stress scores, while increasing HRV scores, with no significant differences between the two delivery methods. Anxiety levels also decreased after each session.
population_specificity: Frontline healthcare workers during the COVID-19 pandemic.
effective_dosage: 30-minute guided sessions every other day for 10 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) alone versus PFMT combined with a home-based pressure-mediated biofeedback (BF) device in treating postpartum stress urinary incontinence (SUI).
results_summary: The study found that PFMT with biofeedback significantly reduced incontinence severity, increased cure and improvement rates, enhanced pelvic floor muscle strength, and improved adherence compared to PFMT alone. The intervention group showed statistically and clinically meaningful benefits across multiple outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with new-onset postpartum stress urinary incontinence in China (median age 34, median BMI 23.71, median time since delivery 50 days).
effective_dosage: Not specified (home-based pressure-mediated BF device used alongside supervised PFMT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of HRV biofeedback training (HRVBF) in improving HRV metrics and mental resilience in police officers.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant increases in HRV metrics, indicating improved autonomic function and stress resilience, along with enhanced mental resilience measured by attentional control, mindful awareness, and reduced fatigue.
population_specificity: 27 Icelandic police officers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of biofeedback in treating pelvic floor dysfunction when combined with additional therapy addressing abnormal core and respiratory function.
results_summary: The study found that biofeedback is effective for pelvic floor dysfunction, but patients experienced more rapid symptomatic improvement when biofeedback was combined with additional therapy targeting core and respiratory function.
population_specificity: Patients with pelvic floor dysfunction and bowel/bladder dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mobile heart rate variability biofeedback (HRV-BfB) training, delivered via digital or live instruction, could reduce workplace stress and burnout symptoms in employees.
results_summary: The study found that four-week mobile HRV-BfB training reduced burnout symptoms and improved sleep quality, with digital instruction showing slightly higher effect sizes than live instruction. However, no significant differences were found between the two instruction formats in HRV parameters.
population_specificity: Employees of a bearing and seal manufacturer (58.9% male, 86.3% full-time, 67.1% office workers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcome of biofeedback therapy in constipated patients with defecatory disorders and assess the efficacy of two diagnostic tools (straining questionnaire and augmented-DRE) in predicting short-term biofeedback response.
results_summary: Biofeedback was effective for refractory constipation due to functional defecation disorders, with 81 out of 131 patients responding. The straining questionnaire and augmented-DRE results strongly correlated with biofeedback response, while isolated pelvic floor abnormalities showed lower response rates.
population_specificity: 131 refractory chronic constipation patients with defecatory disorders failing the balloon expulsion test.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and biofeedback on overactive bladder in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Biofeedback combined with pelvic floor exercises significantly improved urodynamic parameters in patients with multiple sclerosis, though no significant difference was found between biofeedback, TMS, and control groups post-therapy. The abstract suggests biofeedback has a high level of safety and effectiveness, with superiority over TMS in some aspects.
population_specificity: 45 individuals with multiple sclerosis (both sexes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the expanded functionality of the AVATAR system, including biofeedback, for pediatric radiotherapy, focusing on dosimetric effects and system adaptability.
